segments.text: Senator Hatfield, do you give your permission to allow this to be used as quotable material for a research paper?
I, Mark Hatfield, do.
Thank you very much.
As you know, this interview will focus on the Vietnam War and particularly your role in the Vietnam War protest movement.
And specifically,
What instances caused you, as early as the 1965 Governor's Convention, to come out publicly and state your opposition to the war?
Well, I had expressed my reservations in opposition to the war to a goodly number of people privately.
And in 1965,

And I'd made a few speeches around the state, the question-answer period, or I would make some comment about my disbelief that we had a national interest, a national interest that justified getting involved in war in Southeast Asia.
I had seen it purely as a
failure of the French to reestablish its colonial domain and that we were in effect picking up the marbles where the French failed and were finally driven out following the battle of Dien Bien Phu.
So I had a background there of having been in Vietnam while we were allies with Ho Chi Minh against the Japanese in World War II.
But the governor's conference that was held that year in Minneapolis
A number of the Johnson supporters, President Lyndon Johnson supporters, Democrats, were very anxious to use the governor's conference to affirm the president's war policy.
He had gone before the FLCIO and gotten a resolution.
passed affirming his war policy.
He had obtained some similar business group resolutions.
He was looking, reaching out to get as many various groups as he could to go on record passing a formal resolution to support the war policy.
He liked to wave those in his public speeches to indicate that he had the support of Americans and that radicals, the anti-war protesters, were but a very small, vocal, radical minority.
So when the governors met in their annual conference in Minneapolis, a group of his supporters offered a resolution to endorse President Johnson's war policy.
It was not debated at any length.
They tried to ram it through.
I attempted to ask some questions about the scope and why we were doing this, but it nevertheless was ramrodded through.
And at the time the vote was taken, it was a voice vote.
And I made my voice heard.
by voting no.
As I recall, they didn't even ask for the no's.
It was just sort of all those in favor say aye, and I remember that I had to make my voice loud in order to register my no vote.
Well, the meeting adjourned immediately, and we went out into the lobby and
The press was asking for my explanation of my vote when Governor George Romney of Michigan came up and said, well, I voted no, too.

And so I remember Governor Conley coming by, who was then governor of Texas, and interrupted my press conference by shaking his finger in my face and saying, you have done a disservice to your country.
And it was obviously not a popular vote, although I did have some colleagues who said, well, I wish we didn't have that vote.
I respect your negative vote.
If I did that, my constituents would eat me alive.
And so that was how I got into it.
Then, of course, it made a news item.
Well, President Johnson then sent Air Force
his Air Force plane up to Minneapolis to bring us all down to Washington so that we could be briefed.
And as he had us briefed in the White House, George Romney got up and said, well, Mr. President, your briefing has convinced me that you're right.
And so he said, I now support your policy.
I didn't say anything at the time.
And as a meeting then sort of adjourned, President Johnson came over to me and asked me how I felt now.
And I said, well, I still oppose the war.
I had not changed my mind.
I heard nothing that I had not read or heard about before as justification for the war, and I still disagree.
And at that time, he expressed some surprise when I
When he next asked me if I will, do you want to go out and see the press then?
And I said, no, I have no desire to see the press.
I registered my vote down at the governor's conference.
And I have no desire to see the press.
I'd like to avoid the press.
And he looked at me and he said, well, you really believe it then, don't you?
And I said, of course I do.
Very strong convictions on this.
So he had one of his staff people let me out the side door and I escaped the press.
That was sort of the events as I recall them at this time.
Okay, I guess that actually brings up two questions.
One, I read in your book that

You felt that Lyndon Johnson was able to make the war, minimalize the war protest by making it look like the administration versus the hippies and sort of left out all the dissent that was being felt in the country in the middle class and as well as the Senators.
How was he able to do that?
Well, you have to remember the President of the United States has tremendous ability to
manipulate news in which he has been the chief architect.
After all, he can call up a news person or he could call a news conference and the whole nation listens to what the president says.
A governor of a western state does not command that kind of
news coverage and therefore he has the ability to override and more or less mold the news as he wants.
As they say, put a spin on the news.
You have over 500 members of the Congress and here again, 500 members or even two or three that were dissenters at that time, only two in the Senate.
They don't command that kind of news attention.
So the president really has a tremendous advantage.
He's one person speaking for one branch of government.
And obviously, as contrasted to over 500 members speaking for the legislative branch of government, he has an advantage.
And he wanted to portray the war protesters in a stereotype with the Jane Fondas and the hippies, the radicals who were burning down the ROTC buildings on university campuses.
those who were setting firebombs in the streets.
You know, there's nothing that set our effort back more than the radicals who the hypocrisy of using violence to protest violence came through to the American people very clearly.
American people don't have much time for those who are talking about
war and their attitude toward war and then using in effect violence to express themselves to exercise their freedom of speech they weren't helping the cause i can assure you
And as a consequence, he exploited that.

Johnson had, you know, the cameras and the news media loved the action of something that was exploding in the streets or something that was burning a building down, burning the flag and all of those things that the extremists were doing.
It was played on the tube every night, or at least very frequently.
And then you had the...
American soldiers fighting, you know, and dying for, under their government command, government policy.
And the contrast was very, very great.

And I can assure you, as one of those protesters within the establishment, within the government as I was, it made our task very, very difficult to separate ourselves and to have a responsible protest, a legitimate protest,
as against the kind of radical extremists that were out there on the streets.
Were there any groups, protest groups, actually, such as Students for a Democratic Society or Women for Peace, that
you attempted in any way to correspond with and to work towards a positive goal, or did you try to remove yourselves completely from those kind of organizations?
Well, initially, when I was governor, it was difficult to maintain national contact.
I had a lot of mail.
I had telephone calls, and I had organ groups that were protesters with whom I met very regularly.
trying to work out some kind of a rallying point of responsible protest.
It was not until I got to the Senate, which was in 1966 election, that I found that there were a number of senators by now in 1967.
It would have been by January.
I was elected in 66 and sworn in in January.
I found that it had expanded beyond just Wayne Morse and Dr. Greening of Alaska, who had cast the only two votes against the Gulf of Tonkin resolution.
By this time, Senator Fulbright of Arkansas, who was the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was expressing his dissent, and a few other senators.
But the difficulty was what in the world did you rally?
What was the focus of dissent other than just speech-making or this violence and such out on the countryside?
So Senator McGovern and I decided that what we ought to do would be to offer a resolution to cut off the funds prospectively.
So we weren't going to cut off the equipment flowing to our soldiers out there on the battlefront, deny them the opportunity to defend themselves.
But we were making a prospecting that we would, this resolution called for the cutoff of any funds to conduct war as of a certain prospective date.
And this became then the battle cry, the so-called Hatfield-McGovern Amendment.
We had
a professional come down from New York.
I wish I could remember his name.
It's probably in the book.
And we took some television time underwritten by some of the businessmen who were against the war.
And on that television, Frank Church, a Democrat from Idaho, and Harold Hughes, Democrat from Iowa,
George McGovern, Charlie Goodell, Republican from New York State, and myself, as I recall.
Was there one more?
No, I think that was it.
We went on a television prime time and appealed to the American public to support our resolution and to send us contributions.
in order to advertise and to communicate and disperse this resolution and create it as a rallying point.
The Methodist Center up on the hill became the place that these letters came in, and they came in by the thousands.
We were overwhelmed.
We could never believe that the dollar bill, $5, the $20,
that people all over this country sent to be helpful in our effort.
Now, that became the first rallying point of an action that we took from within the institution.
We only had seven co-sponsors, as I recall, a handful.
And we reintroduced it, and that became then
the focus of protest and it got up to 48 votes out of 100 senators and Mr. Nixon by this time had been elected and began to read the signals and that's when he began his plans for withdrawal.
Speaking of Nixon, what
Actually, the McGovern race is more what I'm interested in.
If there was so much anti-war feeling by the time the 72 election rolled around, why was McGovern able to only pull the very limited number of votes that he did in that election?
Did you see any particular reason?
Pardon?
Any particular reason for that?
There were a number of reasons.
First of all, by 72, there were fairly clear signals the administration was moving to find an exit from the war.
In 68, Mr. Nixon had a secret plan.
He said he wasn't going to talk about the war the rest of the time of the election campaign in 68.
And that was against Mr. Humphrey, who was, of course, Mr. Johnson's vice president and was one of the architects of the whole war policy.
By 72, the whole effort in the Congress had focused more clearly.
And I think there were a lot of peripheral issues.
Mr. McGovern.
unfortunately, had a horrible time trying to find a vice presidential running mate.
And he didn't have any idea.
And every day at the convention, Senator Abraham Ribicoff turns McGovern down.
Senator so-and-so turns him down.
He names Senator Eagleton.
And then it comes out Senator Eagleton had had shock treatment for nervous breakdown.
So he went off the ticket.
And then he finally got Sergeant Shriver, Senator Kennedy's brother-in-law, to come on the ticket.
Well, by this time, the public perceived that McGovern couldn't even put a ticket together.
How was he going to run the country?
So there were a lot of really peripheral issues like that, not directly relating to the war, that caused the public to lose confidence that McGovern was equipped or capable of governing.
or becoming president.

Is there any particular action, if you had been able to take the war protesters, I know you say that they were doing things that were actually harmful to the movement itself, if you could have focused them in any one direction, in their public protest or whatever, what direction would you have headed them?
What would you have had all these people, aside from supporting what y'all were trying to do in the Senate, what would you have them do in mainstream Americana, I guess?
Well, bear in mind, all during this time, I was traveling the college campuses, Berkeley, Harvard, Stanford, all over the country, your major large universities as well as some of your smaller ones.
And I had one simple theme, and that is that the focus was on Washington, DC.
Everybody was trying to get to Washington, to have a demonstration in Washington.
And my theme was, Washington is but a reflection of every main street in America.
And they were missing the bet of not visiting the editors of their local papers,

the leaders of their business community who were part of the National Chamber of Commerce, part of the National Association of Manufacturers, part of the AFL-CIO, who were passing these resolutions of support at the national level.
And I said, they're but reflecting the feelings amongst their constituents out in these various communities.
You don't have to come to Washington to have a protest.
You don't have to come to Washington trying to persuade the change of policy.
The policy in Washington is but a reflection of the attitudes and the viewpoints of the people living right in your own neighborhood, right in your own community.
And that's where you should be putting your constructive persuasive protest.
OK.

Do you feel then because maybe they didn't put enough pressure on their local officials or even on their state and national elected officials, I sort of got the feeling from in general reading some of your book that people here in Washington were trying to protect their political futures and not doing what was best for America.
Did you get that feeling?

Well, I know that a lot of the members of Congress were not publicly expressing the same opinion that they were privately expressing in the cloakrooms and elsewhere, because they felt the public sentiment was behind the war.
And at certain periods of this time, it certainly was behind the war.
I believe it was tested out in Oregon that in 1966, when I was running for the Senate, that about 76% of the public did support the war.
So these were great, overwhelming statistics that influenced an awful lot of people in public life who were dependent on that same constituency for their votes.
In your book, you mentioned that you felt

At as early as, well I guess Lyndon Johnson has stated that as early as 1964 he had plans for actually sending more troops in when publicly during his campaign he was saying he was not going to escalate the war.
Do you feel that disinformation campaign contributed to the hotbed of protest or was it an attempt of his to actually combat the protest?
I would have to speculate because I didn't have that kind of close relationship to know what Johnson was saying to his close advisors and what to contrast it with what he was saying publicly.
But I do feel that the fact that later Mr. Nixon expanded the war after his 68 election where he said he had a secret plan to
bring the war to an end, that he wasn't going to debate or discuss or announce in public until after he was elected.
By the way, I wrote him a letter at that time and said that I had been named one of his surrogate candidates to campaign for him and authorized to speak on any issue on his behalf.
And I said, I will have to, in effect, cease my involvement until you're willing to
head on, take head on, the most fundamental, important issue of this campaign.
I said, I just don't think people are going to buy a pig and a poke that you have some secret plan.

Well, remember, after he was elected, he increased and expanded the war into Cambodia by starting the bombing of Cambodia, because he said there was a great communist cache of arms in Cambodia that were being used to
against our fighting forces in Vietnam.
Well, later they never did find the cache of arms that we talked about.

And so when I used Nixon's action to expand the war into Cambodia, it would certainly then follow that, or it could follow that Johnson may have had ideas that were being sold to him about expanding the number of troops to bring the war to a quicker end.
They kept talking about a light at the end of the tunnel.
That was Secretary of Defense McNamara, Robert McNamara, phrased it, well, we see a light at the end of the tunnel.
Well, that was when we had 200,000 there.
And when Johnson left office, it had escalated to 563,000.
We were still seeing the light at the end of the tunnel as we escalated.
So it would have followed in the pattern of Johnson's policy.
I'll take you home.
Johnson...
Yes, sir.
Johnson, in his administration, escalated the war.
Remember, Kennedy sent the first...
When Kennedy became president, there were only 600 advisers that were left there by Eisenhower.
And Eisenhower had resisted sending combat troops.
And at that time, John Foster Dulles, his secretary of state, and later Christian Herder,
and as well as Vice President Nixon were urging Eisenhower to send combat troops.
And he refused.
So when Kennedy then became president, he really, you might say, started the actual war, as far as the United States is concerned, by sending 17,000 combat troops there.
And then when Johnson came in,

But in that period of Johnson's administration, it was a consistent pattern of escalating, always that McNamara and the generals were saying, another 10,000, another 20,000, and we can bring the war to a quicker end.
And it finally got up to 500, and as I recall, 43,000 or 63,000, in excess of 500,000.
So it could well have fallen in that pattern.
Do you...
You've stated in the book as well as in other places that you feel under no circumstances should you break the law to try and make a point.
You state in the book you do not agree with civil disobedience.
What were your personal feelings?
Let me clarify that a little bit.
I do think there's a right of civil disobedience provided you don't use force and violence.
and provided that you stand accountable for your action of civil disobedience.
The idea of committing an act of civil disobedience and running, I did not agree with.
But I think the right of conscience gives to any American the right to disobey the law, provided it is a nonviolent,
action and that one then stands ready to suffer the penalty of that disobedience.

So on the I mean a certain situation such as burning a draft card refusing to if drafted to go into service if they were willing to accept the penalty of their spending the time in jail but not running off to camp.
That's right.
